awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Computational Synthesis of 3D Printed Composite and Infill Layouts
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project expedites the growth of additive manufacturing for end-use parts through automated design software. Additive manufacturing has emerged as an appealing alternative to traditional subtractive manufacturing to fabricate end-use parts with tailored stiffness and strength. A critical production stage required to unlock the potential of additive manufacturing for end-use parts is the design process, which currently requires extensive engineering experience and high engineering design time. The new technology will allow a paradigm shift from the current slow, tedious, and failure-prone design process to an automated design process. The algorithm utilizes high-performance computing and designs components based on strength, specific material properties, and manufacturing constraints. The technology is expected to reduce engineering design time and, as a result, the production cost and time, which will enable the industry to scale production. Additionally, by using the automated design process, the material distribution can be tailored to achieve the desired structural responses, and lightweight structures can be fabricated. The reduction in weight results in a reduction in fuel consumption in aviation and auto industries, which will provide both ecological and economic benefits.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project advances the state of the art by (a) developing novel approaches to optimize layout, fiber paths, and plastic infill distribution, (b) generating additive manufacturing toolpaths based on structural performance and efficiency, and (c) implementing multiple failure criteria to understand failure loads in composite additive manufacturing. Due to the significant cost difference between continuous fiber filament and plastic infill, it is crucial to consider the design of fiber paths, carbon fiber reinforced regions, and plastic infill layout. Another challenge is that current design processes do not include a single failure criterion that can predict failure under different loading scenarios. To address these two challenges, the team is investigating a stiffness and strength-based topology optimization for composite additive manufacturing that will enable the design of the geometric layout and toolpath for 3D printing simultaneously. Anisotropic material properties for stiffness and strength in different directions are implemented to utilize the full potential of composite parts. Toolpath constraints such as curvature, minimum length, and width are also implemented in the optimization process to prevent print failure. Finally, an intelligent slicing program will be developed to control the movement of the 3D printer nozzle and eliminate part failure due to stress concentration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Additive Manufacturing (AM), commonly known as 3D printing, has revolutionized how parts and products are made by offering unparalleled design freedom and the ability to create highly customized, high-performance components. Despite its potential, AM adoption is hindered by limitations in existing design tools, which are often inefficient, inflexible, and produce suboptimal results for advanced manufacturing processes. This project aimed to tackle these challenges by developing a novel software solution to automate and optimize the design process for 3D-printed parts, enabling engineers to create efficient, high-performance products with reduced costs and time.

 

Project Findings and Intellectual Merit

This project developed a design tool that combines automation, optimization, and editability to address critical challenges in AM. Specifically, the tool enables engineers to:

  1. Create Editable Optimized Designs: Traditional design tools often generate complex files that are difficult to modify. Our software incorporates a novel "Performance+Editability Optimization Algorithm," which uses discrete polygon geometries throughout the design process. This method involves iteratively altering the shape, size, location, and orientation of multiple design pieces through their endpoints. This methodology reduces design time by up to 90% while improving usability for engineers. For instance, in a case study of an airplane landing gear component, the software reduced the design’s complexity from 529,358 surfaces in a competitor’s output to just 155 surfaces, while maintaining structural integrity. This led to a compact file size of 0.5 MB, compared to 61 MB in traditional tools, making the design more efficient to handle and modify.

  2. Optimize Material Properties and Toolpaths: The tool optimizes the orientation of anisotropic materials to maximize stiffness and strength. It also generates toolpaths for Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) that align with stress distributions, minimizing material usage and printing time while enhancing structural performance. Furthermore, the software integrates stress-based design criteria to address limitations in traditional stiffness-based optimization. By incorporating failure analysis and adaptive mesh refinement, the tool removes stress singularities and increases part strength by up to 50%, ensuring more reliable and durable components.

  3. Enhance Collaboration with Pilot Customers: During the project, the software was tested with pilot customers from aerospace, automotive, and biomedical sectors, leading to iterative improvements. Feedback highlighted the tool’s ability to deliver high-performance designs tailored to specific engineering and manufacturing requirements. This collaborative approach ensured the tool’s practicality and relevance across diverse applications.

 


Last Modified: 12/03/2024
Modified by: Zhichao Wang

Overview

Despite its potential, AM adoption is hindered by limitations in existing design tools, which are often inefficient, inflexible, and produce suboptimal results for advanced manufacturing processes. This project aimed to tackle these challenges by developing a novel software solution to automate and optimize the design process for 3D-printed parts, enabling engineers to create efficient, high-performance products with reduced costs and time.

This project developed a design tool that combines automation, optimization, and editability to address critical challenges in AM. Specifically, the tool enables engineers to:




Create Editable Optimized Designs: Traditional design tools often generate complex files that are difficult to modify. Our software incorporates a novel "Performance+Editability Optimization Algorithm," which usesdiscrete polygon geometries throughout the design process. This method involves iteratively altering the shape, size, location, and orientation of multiple design pieces through their endpoints. This methodology reduces design time by up to 90% while improving usability for engineers.For instance, in a case study of an airplane landing gear component, the software reduced the designs complexity from 529,358 surfaces in a competitors output to just 155 surfaces, while maintaining structural integrity. This led to a compact file size of 0.5 MB, compared to 61 MB in traditional tools, making the design more efficient to handle and modify.




Optimize Material Properties and Toolpaths: The tool optimizes the orientation of anisotropic materials to maximize stiffness and strength. It also generates toolpaths for Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) that align with stress distributions, minimizing material usage and printing time while enhancing structural performance.Furthermore, the software integrates stress-based design criteria to address limitations in traditional stiffness-based optimization. By incorporating failure analysis and adaptive mesh refinement, the tool removes stress singularities and increases part strength by up to 50%, ensuring more reliable and durable components.




Enhance Collaboration with Pilot Customers: During the project, the software was tested with pilot customers from aerospace, automotive, and biomedical sectors, leading to iterative improvements. Feedback highlighted the tools ability to deliver high-performance designs tailored to specific engineering and manufacturing requirements. This collaborative approach ensured the tools practicality and relevance across diverse applications.
